<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
VII. THE ORIGINALL PERTEYNYNG TO THE CRAFT OF GLOUERES. Sacrificium Cayme et Abell. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Angelus. Caym. Abell. Brewbarret (later addition.)]

[Scene, ? in the field.] 1. Ang. That Lord of Lyffe lele ay lastand, Whos myght vn-mesured is to meyne, He shoppe Ã¾e sonne, both see and sande, And wroughte Ã¾is worlde with worde, I wene. His Aungell cleere, as cristall clene, Here vn-to you Ã¾us am I sente Ãis tide. Abell and Cayme, Ã¾ei both by-deyne, To me enteerly takis entent, To meve my message haue I ment, if Ã¾at ye bide. 2. Alle myghty god of myghtes moste, When he had wrought Ã¾is world so wide, No thynge hym Ã¾oughte was wroughte in waste But in his blissyng boune to bide. Neyne ordurs for to telle, Ã¾at tyde, Of Aungeles bryght he bad Ã¾er be, for pride. And sone Ã¾e tente part it was tried, And wente awaye, as was worthye, They heild to helle all Ã¾at meyne, Ã¾er-in to bide. 3. Ãanne made he manne to his liknes, That place of price for to restore, And sithen he kyd him such kyndnes, Som-what wille he wirke Ã¾er-fore. The tente to tyne he askis, nomore, Of alle Ã¾e goodes he haues you sent, full trew. To offyr loke Ã¾at ye be yore, And to my tale yhe take entent, For ilke-a lede Ã¾at liffe has lente, shalle you ensewe, 4. Abell. Gramercy! god of thy goodnes, That me on molde has marked Ã¾i man, I worshippe Ã¾e with worthynes, With alle Ã¾e comforte Ã¾at I can. Me for to were fro warkes wanne, For to fulfille thy comaundement, Ã¾e teynd Of alle Ã¾e gode sen I be-ganne, Thow shalle it haue, sen Ã¾ow it sent. Come, brother Cayme, I wolde we wente, with hert ful hende. 5. Cay. We! Whythir now in wilde waneand, Trowes Ã¾ou I thynke to trusse of towne? Goo, iape Ã¾e, robard iangillande, Me liste no?t nowe to rouk nor rowne. Abell. A! dere brothir, late vs be bowne Goddis biddyng blithe to fulfille, I tell Ã¾e. Caym. Ya! daunce in Ã¾e devilway, dresse Ã¾e downe, For I wille wyrke euen as I will. What mystris Ã¾e, in gode or ille, of me to melle Ã¾e? 6. Ab. To melle of Ã¾e myldely I may, Bot goode brothir, go we in haste, Gyffe god oure teynde dulye Ã¾is day, He byddis vs Ã¾us, be nou?t abassed. Cay. Ya! deuell me thynkeÃ¾ Ã¾at werke were waste, That he vs gaffe geffe hym agayne, to se. Nowe fekyll frenshippe for to fraste, Me thynkith Ã¾er is in hym sarteyne. If he be moste in myghte and mayne, what nede has he? 7. Ab. He has non nede vn-to Ã¾i goode, But it wille please hym principall, If Ã¾ou, myldly in mayne and moode, Grouche no?t geue hym tente parte of all. Here two leaves have been cut out, If shall be done evyn as ye bydd, And that Anone. [caret inde to Mr. Cayme what shares bryng I.] Brewb. Lo! Mr. Cayme, what shares bryng I, Evyn of the best for to bere seyd. And to the ffeylde I wyll me hye To fetch you moo, if ye haue neyd. Cayme. Come vp! sir knave! the devyll the speyd, Ye will not come but ye be prayd. Brewb. O! maister Caym, I haue broken my to! Cayme. Come vp, syr, for by my thryst, Ye shall drynke or ye goo. [Enter Angel. Ang. Thowe cursyd Came, where is Abell? Where hais thowe done thy broder dere? Cayme. What askes thowe me that taill to tell? For yit his keper was I never. Ang. God hais sent the his curse downe, Fro hevyn to hell, maldictio dei. Cayme. Take that thy self, evyn on thy crowne, Quia non sum custos fratris mei, To tyne. Ang. God hais sent the his malyson, And inwardly I geve the myne. Cayme. The same curse light on thy crowne, And right so myght it worth and be, For he that sent that gretyng downe The devyll myght speyd both hym & the. Fowll myght thowe fall! Here is a cankerd company, Therefore goddes curse light on you all. 8. Ang. What hast Ã¾ou done? be-holde and heere, Ãe voice of his bloode cryeth vengeaunce. Fro erthe to heuen, with voice entere, Ã¾is tyde. That god is greved with thy greuaunce Take hede, I schalle telle Ã¾e tydandis, Ã¾erfore abide. 9. Ãou shall be curssed vppon Ã¾e grounde, God has geffyn Ã¾e his malisonne, Yff Ã¾ou wolde tyll Ã¾e erthe so rounde No frute to Ã¾e Ã¾er shalle be founde. Of wikkidnesse sen Ã¾ou arte sonne, Thou shalle be waferyng here and Ã¾ere, Ã¾is day. In bittir bale nowe art Ã¾ou boune, Out-castyn shal Ã¾ou be for care, No man shal rewe of thy misfare, for Ã¾is affraie. 10. Cay. Allas! for syte, so may I saye, My synne it passis al mercie, For ask it Ã¾e, lord, I ne maye, To haue it am I nou?t worthy. Fro Ã¾e shalle I be hidde in hye, Ãou castis me, lorde, oute of my kyth In lande. Both here and there oute-caste am I, For ilke a man Ã¾at metis me with, They wille slee me, be ffenne or ffrith, with dynte of hande. 11. Ang. Nay, Cayme nou?t soo, haue Ã¾ou no drede, Who Ã¾at Ã¾e slees shalle ponnysshed be Sevene sithis for doyng of Ã¾at dede; For-thy a token shal Ã¾ou see, It shalle be prentyd so in Ã¾e, That ilke aman shalle Ã¾e knowe full wele. Caym. Thanne wolle I ffa[r]dir flee for shame. Sethen I am sette Ã¾us out of seill, That curse that I haue for to feill, I giffe you Ã¾e same.
